jdrasil.graph

Class BitSetGraph<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • jdrasil.graph.BitSetGraph<T>

  • public class BitSetGraph<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object
    A BitSetGraph stores a graph (with arbitrary vertices) as bitwise adjacency matrix, i.\,e., as array of BitSets where the i'th BitSet corresponds to the i'th row of the adjacency matrix. This comes with all the advantages and disadvantages of an adjacency matrix. The crucial advantage is that the graph is compact and that many operations can be performed quickly on the bit level. In particular, dynamic programming over subgraphs can be implemented efficiently, as subgraphs are also just BitSets that can efficiently be hashed.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BitSetGraph

        public BitSetGraph(Graph<T> graph)
        Creates the BitSetGraph from the given graph by computing a bijection from the vertices to $\{0,...,n-1\}$ and storing edges in an adjacency matrix represented by an array of BitSets.
        Parameters:
        graph - The graph to be represented as BitSetGraph.

    • Method Detail

      • getGraph

        public Graph<T> getGraph()
        Getter for the original graph used to create this BitSet graph.
        Returns:
        The original graph.

      • getN

        public int getN()
        Getter for the number of vertices in the graph.
        Returns:
        The number of vertices $|V|$.

      • getBitSetGraph

        public java.util.BitSet[] getBitSetGraph()
        Getter for the BitSet graph: an array of n BitSets where the i'th BitSet corresponds to the i'th row of the adjacency matrix of the graph.
        Returns:
        The adjacency matrix of $G$ as Array of BitSets.

      • getVToInt

        public java.util.Map<T,java.lang.Integer> getVToInt()
        Get the used mapping that maps the vertices to $\{0,...,n-1\}$.
        Returns:
        A map from vertices to ids.

      • getIntToV

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.Integer,T> getIntToV()
        Get the reverse mapping, i.e., from $\{0,...,n-1\}$ to the vertices of the original graph.
        Returns:
        A map from ids to vertices.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        The corresponding BitSet.

      • interiorBorder

        public java.util.BitSet interiorBorder(java.util.BitSet C)
        Gets the interior border of $C$, i.\,e., all vertices $v$ in $C$ that have at least one neighbor outside of $C$.
        Parameters:
        C - A vertex set $C\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        $N(N(C))\cap C$, i.\,e., the vertices inside $C$ that have an outgoing edge.

      • computeExteriorBorder

        public java.util.BitSet computeExteriorBorder(java.util.BitSet C)
        Gets the exterior border of $C$, i.e., all vertices $v$ in $G[V\setminus C]$ that have at least one neighbor in $C$.
        Parameters:
        C - A vertex set $C\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        $N(C)$, i.\,e., the vertices that are reachable from $C$ with a single edge.

      • exteriorBorder

        public java.util.BitSet exteriorBorder(java.util.BitSet C)
        Gets the exterior border of $C$, i.e., all vertices $v$ in $G[V\setminus C]$ that have at least one neighbor in $C$.
        Parameters:
        C - A vertex set $C\subseteq V$. Cashes the result for further use.
        Returns:
        $N(C)$, i.\,e., the vertices that are reachable from $C$ with a single edge.

      • saturate

        public void saturate(java.util.BitSet C)
        Saturates the subgraph $C$ by adding all vertices $v\in N(C)$ of $V\setminus C$ that have all neighbors in $C$ or $N(C)$.
        Parameters:
        C - A vertex set $C\subseteq V$ that should be saturated.

      • absorbable

        public int absorbable(java.util.BitSet C)
        Finds and returns an arbitrary vertex $v\in N(C)$ that has only neighbors in $C$ or $N(C)$. Returns $-1$ if no such vertex exists.
        Parameters:
        C - A vertex set $C\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        An absorbable vertex $v\in C$, or $-1$ if non exists.

      • separate

        public java.util.List<java.util.BitSet> separate(java.util.BitSet S)
        Compute the connected components of $G[V\setminus S]$, $S$ will not be included in any of these components.
        Parameters:
        S - A separator $S\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        A list of the connected components of $G[V\setminus S]$, each represented as BitSet.

      • isPotentialMaximalClique

        public boolean isPotentialMaximalClique(java.util.BitSet K)
        Test if the given set of vertices is a potential maximal clique, i.\,e., a maximal clique in some minimal triangulation of the graph. This method uses the local characterisation of potential maximal cliques found by Bouchitte and Todinca ``Treewidth and Minimum Fill-In: Grouping th Minimal Separators''.
        Parameters:
        K - A subgraph $K\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        True if $K$ is a potential maximal clique.

      • unconf

        public java.util.List<java.util.BitSet> unconf(java.util.BitSet S,
                                               java.util.BitSet K)
        Compute the unconfined components of $G[V\setminus K]$ with respect to $S$, i.\,e., the components $C$ with $N(C)\not\subseteq S$.
        Parameters:
        S - A vertex set $S\subseteq K$.
        K - A vertex set $K\subset V$.
        Returns:
        The set $\mathrm{unconf}(S,K)$ as list of BitSets.

      • crib

        public java.util.BitSet crib(java.util.BitSet S,
                             java.util.BitSet K)
        Compute the crib of $K$ with respect to $S$.
        Parameters:
        S - A vertex set $S\subseteq K$.
        K - A vertex set $K\subset V$.
        Returns:
        $(K\setminus S)\cup\bigcup_{D\in\mathrm{unconf(S,K)}}D$ as BitSet.

      • outbound

        public boolean outbound(java.util.BitSet C)
        Check if the given component is outbound, that is, if it is the minimum of all components with neighborhood $N(C)$. Minimum is defined with respect to the natural order of the vertices and a component is smaller then another if it contains a ``smaller'' vertex.
        Parameters:
        C - A vertex set $C\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        True if $C$ is outbound.

      • outlet

        public java.util.BitSet outlet(java.util.BitSet K)
        Compute the outlet of the given set $K$.
        Parameters:
        K - A vertex set $K\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        The maximum set $N(A)\subseteq K$ over all non-full and outbound components $A$ associated with $K$.

      • support

        public java.util.List<java.util.BitSet> support(java.util.BitSet K)
        Compute the support of $K$.
        Parameters:
        K - A vertex set $K\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        $\mathrm{unconf}(\mathrm{outlet}(K),K)$ as BitSet.

      • fullComponents

        public java.util.List<java.util.BitSet> fullComponents(java.util.BitSet K)
        Compute the full-components associated with $K$.
        Parameters:
        K - A vertex set $K\subseteq V$.
        Returns:
        A list of all components $A\in G[V\setminus K]$ with $N(A)=K$.
